reviewText: Code of the Cactus was made in 1939 and times were simpler then, well, at least as far as B-Westerns were concerned.  Cattle rustlers were the bad guys with plans that had no chance of working out and the gunfights were comical (especially in retrospect).  All of it now looks like child's play compared to modern day action movies and real life terrorists.  There isn't much of interest here, other than Tim McCoy opening his eyes real wide for the camera when trouble's a-brewing.  And his undercover Mexican persona and comical Mexican accent would never be allowed today; it would come off as racist (of course, times were different then; different eras different standards).  I can't figure out if the actors were playing their parts for laughs or if they were trying to be serious.  In McCoy's case, I think he was going for laughs whenever possible, or at least a certain level of jolliness.  The other movie -- which contains some of the same actors -- wasn't much better.  These movies are a trip down memory lane to more simple times.  But as movies go, there's not too much to commend them.  Will I ever watch these movies again?  Probably not.
I love it.  A great DVD and a great purchase.
another great old western dvd. 5 star.

Amazon has no listing for this, so I will put it here.  This is for the VCI DVD-R Tim McCoy Double Feature, Vol. 2.  "Code of the Cactus" from Victory Pictures looks good, but has a handful of dialogue splices and 1 scene that looks to be cut into late.  "Fighting Renegade", also from Victory, has a handful of dialogue splices and some poor audio.  Both films appear to be basically complete based on running times.  Many of these westerns can be found from different sources with dialogue splices in different scenes. When is someone going to put together some of these features from 2-3 sources.

Poverty Row Pictures presents "CODE OF THE CACTUS/OUTLAW'S PARADISE" (1939) (118 mins/B&W) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) --- The American actor Tim McCoy in real life was a sharpshooter and famed for his fast draw --- The Native Americans had no better ambassador than Tim McCoy, a former Indian language translator in real life --- Tim McCoy spoke passionately about this country's longtime abuse of its native population by breaking treaty after treaty --- McCoy an expert on the Old West, also an authority on Indian folklore could converse in Indian sign language --- McCoy was inducted into the "Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum" in 1973, also inducted into "The Cowboy Hall of Fame" in 1974.

The first film of this double feature - "CODE OF THE CACTUS" (25 February 1939) (56 mins/B&W)

Under the production staff of:
Sam Newfield - Director
Sam Katzman - Producer
Edward Halperin - Screenwriter
Marcel Le Picard - Cinematographer
Holbrook N. Todd - Film Editor
Fred Preble - Set Decorator
E.W. Rote - Production Manager
Bert Sternbach - Assistant Director
Fred Preble - Art Dept.
Hans Weeren - Sound Dept
Carl Mathews - Stuntman
Wally West - Stuntman

The story line and plot, our hero 'Steely Eyed' Tim McCoy is in another poverty row quickie western --- 'Lightning' Bill Carson (Tim McCoy) being outbid by Blackton (Forrest Taylor) on cattle contracts --- and is Thurston (Ted Adams) our star villain trying to get the best of McCoy --- will McCoy bring out that Mexican disguise of his and throw in with all the badmen of this picture --- how about Dave O'Brien and Ben Corbett who still thinks Lightning Bill Carson (McCoy) is the best cowboy star since sliced bread --- can we see justice done with all the hard riding, shooting and drama that lies ahead --- must admit, have a great fondness for Tim McCoy playing the continued role of a Mexican character, it is a pleasure to watch him in action --- McCoy made eight Westerns for low-budget producer Katzman's Victory Pictures before signing with newcomer PRC.--- well, don't leave the theater you're about to find excitement in the last reel in this over the top sound B-Western.

the cast includes:

Reed Howes ... Man in Photograph
Carl Mathews ... Henchman
Kermit Maynard ... Henchman
Milburn Morante ... Old Cowhand
Tex Palmer ... Rider
Robert Walker ... Government Agent

Second film of the this double feature - "OUTLAW'S PARADISE" (19 April 1939) (62 mins/B&W)

Under the production staff of:
Sam Newfield - Director
Sam Katzman - Producer
Basil Dickey - Screenwriter
Marcel Le Picard - Cinematographer
Holbrook Todd - Editor

The story line and plot, our hero Tim McCoy in a dual role, as gang leader Trigger Mallory (Tim McCoy) is about to be released from prison --- When William 'Lightning Bill' Carson (also Tim McCoy) notices the resemblance, convinces the Warden (Jack Mulhall) to hold Mallory and he assumes his identity --- Carson fools both the gang and Trigger's girlfriend Jessie Treadwell (Joan Barclay) as he sets them up to be captured --- But Trigger escapes from prison and returns to expose the hoax and Bill is made a prisoner --- What follow then, is excitement and action that only Tim McCoy can muster --- One of McCoy's best.

the cast includes:
Tim McCoy ... Captain William 'Lightning Bill' Carson / Trigger Mallory
Joan Barclay ... Jessie Treadwell
Ben Corbett ... Magpie Magillicuddy
Ted Adams ... Slim Marsh
Forrest Taylor ... Henchman Eddie
Bob Terry ... Henchman Steve
Donald Gallaher ... Henchman Mort
Dave O'Brien ... Henchman Meggs
Jack Mulhall ... Prison Warden
Ed Cassidy ... Banker
Wally West ... Bank Teller
Lloyd Whitlock ... Reporter

BIOS:
1. Tim McCoy (aka: Timothy John Fitzgerald McCoy)
Birth Date: 4/10/1891 - Saginaw, Michigan
Died: 1/29/1978 - Nogales, Arizona

If you crave action, drama and plenty of adventure check out other western double features --- Ask Amazon. Com to carry the volumes as they are not available on Amazon as of yet --- you can order and pick up your copy now from VCI Entertainment

TIM McCOY WESTERN DOUBLE FEATURES - VCI Entertainment:
Vol 1: End of the Trail & Lightning Carson Rides Again
Vol 2: Code of the Cactus & Fighting Renegade
Vol 3: Bulldog Courage & Ghost Patrol
Vol 4: Roarin' Guns & The Traitor
Vol 5: Trigger Fingers & Phantom Ranger
Vol 6: Fighting Shadows & Justice of the Range
Vol 7: Cornered & Daring Danger
Vol 8: Six Gun Trail & Prescott Kid
Vol 9: Riding Tornado & Riding Wild

Also available from VCI Entertaiment:
ROUGH RIDERS WESTERN DOUBLE FEATURE (Tim McCoy, Buck Jones and Raymond Hatton)
Vol 1: Arizona Bound & Gunman From Bodie
Vol 2: Ghost Town Law & Below the Border
Vol 3: Forbidden Trails & Down Texas Way

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc) and Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- If you're into the memories of B-Westerns with high drama, this is the one you've been anxiously waiting for --- please stand up and take a bow --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 118 min on VHS/DVD ~ Poverty Row Pictures ~ (10/30/2007)
